text: this is Rick Burke for the New York
Times as the investigation continues
into the bombings in Boston officials
are relying much more on social media
years ago there might have been a single
video clip from a surveillance camera
but now investigators can gather
thousands of hours of smartphone footage
we see social media being used by law
enforcement and all different capacities
and certainly each year we see an
exponential growth in how law
enforcement using social media and the
cases that they're applying social media
to for example ICP there's an annual
social media survey of how law
enforcement agencies are using social
media and back in 2011 about 40% of
agencies were soliciting tips from the
public fast forward to 2012 it was
nearly 60 percent of agencies in Boston
investigators are making repeated
requests for video and photographic
submissions hoping for clues the last
thing I want to say is there has to be
hundreds if not thousands of photographs
or videos or observations that were made
down at that finish line yesterday and
they're sitting out there amongst
everyone that's watching this event this
morning and I would encourage you to
bring forward anything you might not
think it's significant but it might have
some value to this investigation David
your company works both with private
clients and law enforcement clients and
mining digital data for investigations
for security reasons and something like
the Boston bombings would what's the
first thing the experts do in looking at
the data in the social media space
particularly they're going to be looking
first off at the different ways they can
search social media they can search the
social media streams if you will on a
geographic basis or with keywords across
all the Twittersphere
or by individuals can you paint us the
scene of what you think may be going on
with the digital evidence from Boston
are there people just sitting there
looking very closely at frame-by-frame
of you know the final leg of that race I
imagine individuals are certainly
looking at it frame by frame very
carefully but also especially in the

is a collection phase that needs to

frame-by-frame searches screen captures
of items of interest and trying to
organize them there will be other

difficult to actually collect down the
road and and candidly the social media
investigative capabilities have come an
extremely long way in the last year but
it's relatively immature when compared
to things like computer forensics is it
your sense that this case could be
cracked somewhere on digital space well
I'm relatively confident that law
enforcement will be using social media
for conducting a piece of their
investigation LexisNexis did a survey a
few I don't know by several months ago
where they surveyed 1,200 individuals
and law enforcement professional
investigators 87 percent of them said to
one degree or another they were using
social media tools for investigations
and 2/3 of those felt that it absolutely
sped up the investigations because it's
a very effective tool for finding
connections between individuals and
times etc it's it's it's a great tool
it's almost like a diary that's online
